text:
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Alice Jackson Newton

Address: 123 Main Street, Saskatoon, Sask.

Birthplace: England

Occupation: Homemaker

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping? 1920

Where did you set up housekeeping? Saskatoon

How long before that? 1914

For how many people did you prepare meals? 5

For how many years? 1914-1920

How often could a visit be made to the store? Not often

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

The type of food you could get most easily included:

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of flour did you use in the early years? None

In what quantities did you buy? 100 lbs

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50

How much did you use grams? 100

Was flour milled locally? Yes

Was flour milled locally? Yes

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.50

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal? Yes

Whole Wheat? No

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? With a hand mill

May 5, 1955
You know we didn't have can
milk then I can remember,
how did we get fresh meat well
in winter we butchered around any fig
and kept until spring that
is if you had them

we could get fish any time
not like now for if you are
seen doing things by the fishing lake
you would be hunted
them smart the good old days
got our meat any way you
could at any old time
and as for fish we tried close to
fishing lake so could get fish all
summer or winter
You know we didn't have can

I will that I can remember.

Now did we get fresh meat well

in winter we butchered a cow and fry

Am it kept until spring that

it if you had them

we could get fish any time

not like them for it if you are

seen anything by the fishing lake

you are ruined! be warned!

them many the good old days.

got your meat any way you

could an at any old time

and as for fish our tried close &

fishing lake so cannot get fish often

summer or winter
This single tax black tea was $3 when it had a twist in the box wood handles an steel blade was fitted this tea an then we got a knife and fork.

From the time my father first started farming in 1879 he grew all his own vegetables in his garden every kind an lots of potatoes I did can fruit but my mother canned fruit to store the food in 1880 she dried a lot of fruit such as apples an watermelon.
This single tea black tea was $5.44 when it had a mark in the box. Wood handles an steel blades was shipped this tea an then we got a deal on fresh.

From the time my father first started farming in 1879 he grew all his own vegetables. Every kind an lots of potatoes I did can fruit but my motto canned fruit is to keep the flavor in 1880 an old friend a lot of fruit such as apples an watermelons.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? (Tea, coffee, etc.) As what price? $2.50

That kind of coffee did you buy? (Instant or ground) Ground

Price? $1.50

That other beverage, how much did you buy? (Tea, coffee, etc.)

That kind of coffee did you buy? (Tea, coffee, etc.)

Price? $1.50

That other beverage, how much did you buy? (Tea, coffee, etc.)

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel then? $1.50

Could you get potatoes at that time? Yes

If not, where from? Nebraska

That year did you grow your own supply for the winter of? 1894

Potatoes

Carrots

Onions

Turnips

Grapes

Beets

In what quantities did you buy berries? (Including grapes)

How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box?)

That weight? 10 lbs.

For did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?

That was the price of prunes? $1.00

What other dried fruits did you use in the winter? (Apricots, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others?)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by it? Yes

Beans?

Corn?

Other foods?

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1897

That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? We didn't

That year did you first preserve meat by canning? We didn't

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning

To what extent? To a great extent

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes

     - Price?

   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (Apples, peaches, apricots, plums, cherries, currants, or others)?

     - Yes

My mother got yeast in the stores when I was a girl in 1885.

That was in Campbell store in Prince Albert.

It was in boxes about 6 little round cakes & a box.

The name royal giant, out of date she made her own yeast.

We didn't get seeded raisins long ago they all had the seeds in them an they were lovely.
My mother got yeast in the store when she was a girl in 1885.

That was my Campbell Store in Prince Albert.

It was in boxes about 6 little round cakes & a box.

The name Royal Giant, out of date.

She made her own yeast.

We didn't get seeded raisins long ago they all had the seeds in them and they were lovely.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes
Using starter? Yes
Using hops? Yes
Salt rising? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Did you buy baking powder? No
Cream of tartar? Did you make your own baking powder? No

They seem have been lots of
changes since I started house
keeping they wrote times when
we didn't have a great curtain
of water but we sure have lots
of it now.

I just can't give you the right year
of all these things. Didn't know,
they are a lot right now then
city water them

Well we have had lots
of water as well have a good
well close & the house an good
water in it ever sense
I started house keeping in
1897. Then no change in
the water supply they started
house keeping.
They have been lots of
cleaning done & started house
keeping city quite times when
we didn't have a great curtain
of water but we sure saw lots
of it move.

I just can't give you the right time
of all these things you know,
they are a lot higher now then
city was then.

Well we have had lots
of water as we have a good
well close & the house an good
water in it even some
started house keeping in

1897. Been no change in
the water supply since started
house keeping.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ________

How far was this water from your home? ________

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ________

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We always had lots of water, but they were lots of people that didn't have much water or not good.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) How far was this water from your home? How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We always had lots of people that didn't have much water on hot days.
My Mother made her own soap for years with wood & lard on any old grease she had.

Mother first got in 1871

you ask about cooking well my mother used a fireplace when she first came out & living in 1878 for a few years until they got a stove up from Winnipeg they could get one in Prince Albert as they had to ship all their goods up from Winnipeg by oxen or waggon an' with horses.
My mother made her own soap for years with wood ashes on any old grease she had.

Another question you ask about cooking well my mother used a fireplace when she first came out & living in a tent came out for a few years until they got a stove up from Winnipeg where they got one in Prince Albert as they had to ship all their goods up from Winnipeg on mule skinners.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Where did you get your fuel? Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping.

I have used wood ever since I started housekeeping 57 years ago. We used a little coal at nights in (age) the winter but the wood & corn will do best.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Did you use an outdoor fireplace or brick oven? By whom was your first cook stove made? What year was it purchased? What types of utensils did you use? For preparing food? When did you first see enamel ware? Aluminum?

I am not sure of this enamel an aluminum was after all it is a long time ago.
13. SOAP:
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?
If you made your own, did you use lye? What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL:
What fuel did you use in the earliest days?
Where did you get your fuel?
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping; giving dates where possible.

I have used wood ever since I started housekeeping 57 years ago. We used a little coal at nights in the winter but the wood & corn was the best.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS:
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)
By whom was your first cook stove made?
What year was it purchased?
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homeware, glass)
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)
When did you first see enamel ware? (Give dates)
Aluminum?

I am not sure of this enamel an aluminum was after all.

It is a long time ago.
Well the worrying times are over ago.

must have been from the start

are what did they hurt the sugar

are team for sugar came by the way shop

and tea are big hopes on current reasons

all came in large box

I was told once long ago that I could

make a meal out of little almost nothing

but then it took a good cook to

get along in them days
Well the unwrapping papers are from Chicago.

Must have been from the store.

Are what did they hurt the sugar?

Are they sugar came by the way?

And tea in big hopes on current balance.

All come in large box.

I was told once long ago that I could

Make a meal out of little almost nothing.

But then it took a good cook to

Get along in them days.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received
with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

The wrapping was paper or cardboard
quad paper bags in 1890.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family
with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or
summer.

Well for breakfast we had
porridge or oatmeal if you had enough
dinner. What an occasion an for supper
what ever you had to eat
after all you made meals out of whatever
you had.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Well I serve my first Christmas dinner in
(put name) was married, 1897
well my mother always had a good dinner
and they only had their family pleasant
they didn't have a big spread like they have now

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally
produced foods? Give date(s).

No I was never & starvation the cause
we missed a lot and had something
on hand before you got down to nothing
no body needed to go hungry if you want
all & much as they want lots of milk meat
& hog fat, can you want store on meat
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers used
with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Quilted paper bags in 1890.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family
with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or
summer.

Well, for breakfast we had
porridge an' meat an' bread an' butter
what ever you had for supper
after all you made meals of whatever
you had.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Well, I served my first Christmas dinner in
[year missing] was married, 1897
well my mother always had a good dinner
and they only had three family pleasant
they didn't have a big third like they have now

19. Have you ever returned to almost starvation level living on one or two locally
produced foods? Give details.

No, I was never in starvation but something
we missed a meal or two down & nothing
for hard before you got down & nothing
no body needed to go hungry if you were
able to work as they were, cats & milk next
so he got, am you want some on meat
You think of nearly experiences of
shearing & sores will I an
mark out like my self and they
in 1895, and I got married
my youngest is 13 year old a family.
yet any help in these days like they do
now from the government I have
been a worker over 30 years and I
raised my family on me all ways
had enough & eat an lot
we bought are groceries an we
grow most every thing else we
needed that is more then a lot
of them old & dry.
You think of early experiences of
speaking with an
Mark Cole, like me I got married
in 1895, and raised 8 of a family.
My youngest is Egyptian and didn't
get any help in them days like they do
now. From the government I have
been a widow over 30 years and
raised my family on me all ways
had enough & eat an extra meal,
we bought our groceries on our
own most every thing else we
needed that is more than a lot
of them do today.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

well as for meal in 1880 you could get a good meal for 25¢ but now not much food no meal

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We never rely on purchased foods we always had lots of home grown foods an much as ever bread an butter but now day not half of the women makes their own bread why not if they want milk a cow.

not rely on milk

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, provisions, storage, shortages and other details.

I am sure they are a lot of different in the merchandising used for 1850 an good deal could get good price for 1850 as fast storage of goods for 1850 as soon as you could all kind room & store things away for I never had much but what I would put it away.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

well as for meal in 1870 you could get a good meal for $3.50 but now not much for a meal

21. How did you begin to rely on purchased foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We never rely on purchased foods. We all always had lots of home grown foods on hand. Bread and butter was made by our own hands. Women of the house milked cows.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include prices mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, types of storage, shortages and other details.

Well I am sure they are a lot of difficult in the merchandising. We used to buy goods you could get good deal for $3.50 as flour storage of course you could all kind room to store things away for I never had much but what I could put it away.
will I have done the best I could

filling this paper out all through I have

been hear in this Kinistino district all

my life since 1870 am I have been a good

lot of changes in the prairies of every

thing since then on then another

thing we didn't get help from the government

so I think it is harder to get along.

now there was 65 years ago.

they think they have to have the best

of every thing now as they just can't get along.

you hear the people of today talk about

hard times they don't know any

think a hard hard times what they had

60 or 70 years ago you used what you

had or could get an was happy we didn't

have near the sickness then as what they

have now, hard to go miles for a doctor

so you didn't get sick if you could bullet

to you hole this will tell you out some,

will by a real old timer

sent in Miss Alice Newtons

Kinistino ranch
Will I have done the best I could
filling this paper out all through? I have
been here in this Kinistino district all
my life since 1870 am I have seen a great
lot of changes in the course of every
thing since then an other another
thing we didn't get hold from the government
to raise a family like they do now,
so I think it is harder to get along,
now there was 65 years ago.
they think they have & have the best
of every thing now all they just can't get along.
you hear the people of today talk about
hard times they don't famous any
think a hard hard times what you
60 or 70 years ago you used happy we didn't
had an could got an run happy as what they
have near the sickness city as what they
have moved hard go if you could help
do you listen out week if you could help
will by a real old timer
sent me Miss Alice Newtons
